Description: Terracotta cooking stove fragment. A pot-support: a theatre mask of Dionysos or a satyr, with a simple wreath of small circles above his hair, and with a long striated beard, within a rectangular panel. The back is plain. The support and panel were made in a one-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Egyptian 3rd to 2nd century BC parallel (Bayer Niemeier 1988, no.764). Similar style and fabric to Naukratis parallel (Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1818). Bayer Niemeier , E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten, Melsungen.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (LA.28) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
